post_text: Our staff engaged in this book study last year and are ready for #nochildleftinside 2020 edition!
shared_text:
1000 Hours Outside
August 2 at 2:00 PM ·

"Ideally, kids of all ages should get AT LEAST three hours of free play outdoors a day."

All parents, teachers and caregivers should read "Balanced and Barefoot: How Unrestricted Outdoor Play Makes for Strong, Confident, and Capable Children" by Angela Hanscom. It's a life-changing read. Our educational pursuits need to reflect the biological needs of children.

Learn more about Angela Hanscom at TimberNook.

post_text:
COVID REOPENING UPDATE:

Yesterday, the state released the Covid Reopening Plan Template that schools must create, submit for board approval, and then submit to the state. This document is based off of the Safe Schools Roadmap found here: https://www.michigan.gov/documents/whitmer/MI_Safe_Schools_Roadmap_FINAL_695392_7.pdf.

Please know that we are working very hard to get Kingsbury's plan completed well ahead of the mid-August deadline.

While we know there are many questions floating around about transportation, facemasks, cleaning procedures, academic instruction, athletics, and more, we ask that you sit tight and allow us to follow the state's guidelines in creating our plan. We will share this with you as soon as possible.

Additionally, you will be hearing from the new KPA board soon regarding furniture donations/loans for our outdoor classrooms. As many people have pointed out, taking learning outdoors is a monumental task and it will require the effort of our entire community to be a success.

Stay tuned.
shared_text:
MICHIGAN.GOV
www.michigan.gov

Additionally, you will be hearing from the new KPA board soon regarding furniture donations/loans for our outdoor classrooms. As many people have pointed out, taking learning outdoors is a monumental task and it will require the effort of our entire community to be a success.

Stay tuned.

post_text:
In these trying times in our nation, we hope that you are all staying safe and sane. A global pandemic, continued racial injustice, and fractured American politics have resulted in a time when our country is not at its proudest moment.

At Kingsbury, we will continue to instill the values of our nation through a global and peaceful lens. We will maintain our high academic standards while making sure students have a firm understanding of privilege and prosperity. Even though our children are shielded from most current events, it is our job to prepare them to be reasonable, rationale adults who can handle any obstacle, big or small, that they might be presented with in the future.

Martin Luther King, Jr. stated, “Darkness cannot drive out darkness; only light can do that. Hate cannot drive out hate; only love can do that.”

Our America needs more kindness and love than ever before.

post_text:
A student’s 8th Grade year at Kingsbury is filled with special moments and activities. The abrupt end of on-site instruction means that our departing 8th Graders will miss many of these treasured memories.

We would still like to make this last year at Kingsbury special for our 8th Graders and we need your help! We are inviting our families to “adopt” an 8th Grade student for the remainder of the school year - or as long as you like. Families that are matched with participating 8th Graders are asked to send encouraging notes, cards, trinkets, treats, etc. to celebrate their graduation from Kingsbury. Our goal is to ensure that each 8th Grader feels encouraged, celebrated and connected to our special community!

Learn more at www.kingsburyparentassociation.org/celebr8

Questions? Contact the KPA at kpa@kingsburyschool.org or Mr. Poirier at dpoirier@kingsburyschool.org.

post_text:
Over the past year, we have surveyed parents, deliberated with our school board, and received faculty input to create our school calendar. With Labor Day being late next year AND the early end to the current year, you will notice that we will be starting early next year on August 24, 2020 and our last day will be June 4, 2021.

Additionally, we have reduced the overall number of half days next year. A more detailed calendar will be forthcoming with all of our Kingsbury events.
text:

With Labor Day being late next year AND the early end to the current year, you will notice that we will be starting early next year on August 24, 2020 and our last day will be June 4, 2021.

Additionally, we have reduced the overall number of half days next year. A more detailed calendar will be forthcoming with all of our Kingsbury events.

post_text: Get outside in 2020.
shared_text:
1000 Hours Outside
January 1 at 5:30 PM ·

Allowing children the time they need to play freely outside is not a new or original concept. Nature play is something kids have done since the dawn of time. From that perspective, this is the most ordinary thing we could be doing for our kids. And yet, current research shows that the average American child only gets 4-7 minutes of daily free play outside.

In just a few short decades, childhood has largely moved indoors and yet the basic tenants of child development have not changed. Kids still need outside play in order to fully develop in every facet.

By committing to nature play, you are giving your child the gift a beautiful childhood in the here and now as well as lifelong advantages for the time still to come.

Join the challenge! Play outside!
Free downloadable tracking sheet available here: https://1000hoursoutside.com/tracker.html
text:
Get outside in 2020.

post_text: Please continue to reach out on our behalf. Our students deserve equitable funding.
shared_text:
Michigan's Charter Schools
October 8, 2019 at 9:48 AM ·

‼️ It’s now been one full week since Governor Gretchen Whitmer cut a funding increase for charter schools, while OK’ing it for other public school students. Together, over 8,000 of us have spoken out to the Governor & our elected officials - but there’s been NO ACTION. On Oct. 20, 150,000+ students will be affected when the first State Aid payment arrives. Here’s how you can continue using your voice:

1. Call Governor Whitmer’s office at 517-373-3400
2. Search for your local Senator at bit.ly/findMIsenator, look up their office number & give them a call.
3. Search for your local State Representative at bit.ly/findMIhouserep, look up their office number & give them a call.

Rock your phone call by covering these key topics: bit.ly/2oqJ4sD 👊🏼

Please continue to reach out on our behalf. Our students deserve equitable funding.

post_text:
What does taking action mean when you are an IB school? There are many ways students might initiate action!

Mrs. Ligon's 2nd graders are learning all about a unit on communities. Through student wonderings about helping other communities, the students decided they wanted to set-up a lemonade stand so they could send money to people impacted by recent hurricanes. What an action they took! The class made $150.00, and the money will be sent to The American Red Cross Relief Hurricane Dorian victims.

What an action they took! The class made $150.00, and the money will be sent to The American Red Cross Relief Hurricane Dorian victims.

post_text: Please contact a legislator on our behalf. Our students deserve the same funding increase as everyone else.
shared_text:
CHARTERSCHOOLS.ORG
Whitmer slashes funding increase for charter school with veto

Michigan's Charter Schools is feeling angry.
October 1, 2019 at 11:31 AM ·

‼️ In a devastating move, Governor Gretchen Whitmer used a line item veto to eliminate the originally proposed budget increase of $240 per-pupil for charter school students, and charter school students alone. Charter students will be affected as early as Oct. 20, 2019.

Act now to tell your elected officials this is NOT ok.
bit.ly/actnow-micharterfunding

text:
Michigan's Charter Schools is feeling angry.
October 1, 2019 at 11:31 AM ·

‼️ In a devastating move, Governor Gretchen Whitmer used a line item veto to eliminate the originally proposed budget increase of $240 per-pupil for charter school students, and charter school students alone. Charter students will be affected as early as Oct. 20, 2019.

Act now to tell your elected officials this is NOT ok.
bit.ly/actnow-micharterfunding

post_text: Thanks to all who came out to the work bee today! Our trail marker system and story book trail are almost complete. Navigating our trail system should be a piece of cake now!
